node.title: Chunky Farmhouse Coffee Table
node.content:
Build your own coffee table! The PDF plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the coffee table are 54" L x 29" W x 18" H

Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.title: Pallet TV Stand
node.content:
Build your own pallet tv stand! The PDF plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the tv stand are 45” W x 15” L x 21” H.

This entire project was constructed from pallet boards. Before beginning this build, break down a few pallets and set aside the lumber. Remember, always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always predrill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.instructions_0_instructions_content: First, build the tabletop and middle/bottom shelves. Glue each of the boards together and clamp till wood glue dries, Then, use 3/4” screws to fasten the cross member for added weight support. NOTE: The middle and bottom shelves have the same measurements.

node.title: Sliding Barn Door
node.content:
Give your home the Farmhouse with a sliding barn door. Not only are they ascetically pleasing, but are a great solution for small spaces. Since they slide against the wall, you don't have to worry about a door swinging open and being in the way. This was the problem that I had in my small home. As I would walk down the hallway I'd constantly be navigating through a maze of doors. That's when I realized that a barn door would resolve this problem and created plans for everyone to do the same. The PDF plans, which will be posted soon, include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions.

Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.
node.excerpt: Build your own Sliding Barn Door for under $140! Give your home the farmhouse style, inspired by Joanna Gaines, for cheap.
node.imagealttext: Sliding Barn Door|Sliding Barn Door||Biscuit Joiner|Drill Pocket Holes|Miter Saw|Mending Plate
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
To get the reclaimed barn door look, check out seller's marketplaces for some old barn wood or go to your local hardware store and purchase your desired lumber. Also, I have provided links below to purchase all the necessary hardware.
  • 1 - 2” x 8” x 10’
  • 2 - 2” x 8” x 8’
  • 3 - 1” x 6” x 8’
  • 1 - 1” x 4” x 8’
  • Sliding Barn Door Kit
  • Barn Door Handle
  • Mending Plate
  • 11/4” Kregg Screws
  • 21/2” Kregg Screws
  • #20 Biscuits
  • Pocket Plugs
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
Here is a list of all the tools I recommended. If you don't have a specific tool, for your convenience I have provided links to purchase each item.
  • Wood Glue
  • Tape Measure
  • Speed Square
  • Pencil
  • Safety Glasses
  • Ear Protection
  • Kreg Jig
  • Drill
  • Drill Bit Set
  • Sander
  • Miter Saw or Circular Saw
  • Bar Clamps
node.instructions_0_instructions_content:
Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions. First, cut the center slats. Apply wood glue on the edge of each center slat. Clamp together while glue drys. Then, cut the center divider. Make sure the center divider length is equal to the width of the slated panels. Next, cut the sides. Make sure the length of the sides equals the height of the slated panels plus the center divider. Finally, cut the top and bottom of the door. Make sure the top and bottom length equal the width of the sides plus the slated panel width.

Note: Many of these cuts are best made as you go. Please be sure your lumber dimensions match the dimensions in the cut list. Sizing can vary depending on the moisture content.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content:
Drill pocket holes with the Kreg Jig indicated in the PDF plans. Apply wood glue between the center divider, slated panels, and each side. Fasten center divider and sides with 2 1/2” Kreg Screws and fasten slated panels and sides with 1 1/4” Kreg Screws. Clamp together while glue drys.

Note: The ovals indicate the pocket hole locations. Please reference the Kreg Jig instructions for the specific settings for the wood thickness. The center panels will use a smaller setting.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Connect the top and bottom boards. Drill pocket holes with the Kreg Jig indicated in the PDF plans. Apply wood glue and fasten with 21/2” Kreg Screws. Use 11/4” Kreg Screws to fasten the top and bottom to the slated panel. Clamp together while glue drys.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Cut the angled boards. Cut one end of the 1x4 at a 45-degree angle. Place the board across the slated panel and mark the next angled cut. Do this for the top and bottom.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Add the Sliding Barn Door Kit hardware. Please read the instructions that come with the kit.  Then screw on the Mending Plates for extra support and the Barn Door Handle. I painted mine black for a more industrial look. Fill all the Kreg holes with a little wood glue and the Pocket Plugs. Sand down the door and stain as desired.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Hang the door. If the door is being pushed out due to your molding, just move the sliding door J brackets to the backside of the door. This will give you the extra space you need for the molding.

node.title: Chalkboard
node.content: Spice up any wall with this easy DIY chalkboard. The PDF plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions to build a 25" x 31" chalkboard. The actual chalkboard size is 18" x 24". Also, check out my custom chalkboard artwork on my Etsy shop. You can find various printable quotes and designs to easily trace out and recreate! Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck! Follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.title: Printable Chalkboard Art
node.content: Create your very own professional looking chalkboards! Find a list of all the necessary supplies, an easy step-by-step guide, and shop various printable chalkboard designs. Also, check out my post for building a DIY chalkboard. Don't forget to follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.
node.excerpt: Create your very own professional looking chalkboard with an easy step-by-step guide. Shop various designs, find a list of all supplies necessary, and see how to create a chalkboard.
node.imagealttext: Step 5 Chalkboard Printables|Chalkboard Printable Artwork|Baking up something sweet chalkboard|Step 2 Chalkboard Printables|Step 1 Chalkboard Printables|Step 3 Chalkboard Printables|Step 4 Chalkboard Printables|Step 6 Chalkboard Printables
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
Find everything you need here!
  • Chalkboard Stencil (Shop Stencils Here)
  • Chalkboard
  • Chalk
  • Chalk Pencil
  • Masking Tape
  • Scissors
  • Sharpener
  • Graphite Pencil
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Print the artwork to fit within your chalkboard dimensions. I would recommend leaving a 1-2" space around the artwork. When printing, you can either get a large format print from your local printing store or select 'poster' in the printing settings on your printer. This setting will print out the artwork on multiple pieces of 8.5"x11 paper. Once printed, cut and tile the pages together.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Rub a layer of chalk on the back of the print. If you can see the artwork through the paper, try to color only over the text/art. This will reduce unwanted chalk to transfer.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Tape the artwork to the chalkboard face up. <ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display: block;" data-ad-format="fluid" data-ad-layout-key="-6t+1h-j9+7g+1mi" data-ad-client="ca-pub-3133257559155527" data-ad-slot="1633418282"></ins>
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Take a pencil and sketch over the text/art. Be sure to go over all black areas. Be sure not to rest your hand on the chalkboard to prevent any unwanted chalk transfer.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Remove the artwork and you'll see a transfer of the art on the chalkboard. Take your chalk pencil and go over all the text/art. If you want a more permanent chalkboard, use a chalk marker.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Seal the artwork with a light layer of hairspray. This will prevent the chalk from smudging. Also, check out my post for building a DIY chalkboard.

node.title: Farmhouse Table
node.content:
Build your own farmhouse table! The PDF plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the farmhouse table are 33” W x 72” L x 31 1/2” H.

Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.instructions_0_instructions_content: First, build the tabletop. Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions and drill each board with the pocket holes indicated in the drawing below. Apply wood glue between each board and fasten with 21/2” Kregg screws. Clamp together while glue drys. Be sure to fasten the end boards last. The centerboards need to have a clean-cut across, so the ends sit flush. You can trim them up with a circular saw.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content:
Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions for the table base. Drill each board with the pocket holes indicated in the drawing below. The pocket holes will be used to fasten the tabletop. Glue together a plain board and a board with pocket holes together to create a thickness of 1 1/2”. Keep the pocket holes facing towards the outside.

*Note: 1x4’s are used since they have a sharp/clean edge, but you can opt to use 2x4’s to prevent the joining of two 1x4’s.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Cut the table legs and assemble the base. Use 2 1/2” Kregg screws to attach each cross member to the leg. Start with the ends of the table base and be sure to in-set the cross member 1/2” from the outside. See step 5 for clarification.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Attach the long cross members to the assembled table base ends. Be sure to in-set the cross member 1/2” and keep the pocket holes facing the inside of the table.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Attach the center support to the table base with 2 1/2” Kregg screws. Make sure the center support is flush with the other boards.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Attach the tabletop. Use 2 1/2” Kregg screws and attach the tabletop by the pocket holes drilled in step 2. Make sure there is a 2” space on all sides.

First, build the tabletop. Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions and drill each board with the pocket holes indicated in the drawing below. Apply wood glue between each board and fasten with 21/2” Kregg screws. Clamp together while glue drys. Be sure to fasten the end boards last. The centerboards need to have a clean-cut across, so the ends sit flush. You can trim them up with a circular saw.

,

Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions for the table base. Drill each board with the pocket holes indicated in the drawing below. The pocket holes will be used to fasten the tabletop. Glue together a plain board and a board with pocket holes together to create a thickness of 1 1/2”. Keep the pocket holes facing towards the outside.

*Note: 1x4’s are used since they have a sharp/clean edge, but you can opt to use 2x4’s to prevent the joining of two 1x4’s.

,

Cut the table legs and assemble the base. Use 2 1/2” Kregg screws to attach each cross member to the leg. Start with the ends of the table base and be sure to in-set the cross member 1/2” from the outside. See step 5 for clarification.

,

Attach the long cross members to the assembled table base ends. Be sure to in-set the cross member 1/2” and keep the pocket holes facing the inside of the table.

,

Attach the center support to the table base with 2 1/2” Kregg screws. Make sure the center support is flush with the other boards.

,

Attach the tabletop. Use 2 1/2” Kregg screws and attach the tabletop by the pocket holes drilled in step 2. Make sure there is a 2” space on all sides.

node.title: Heavy Metal Detox Smoothie
node.content: This smoothie is not only delicious, it's also perfectly designed to include five key ingredients that work together in synergy to pull heavy metals like mercury, lead, aluminum, nickel, copper, and cadmium out of your organs where they accumulate. To read more about heavy metals and the affects on the body, check out this post. https://www.medicalmedium.com/blog/heavy-metal-detox-smoothie Source: https://www.medicalmedium.com/
node.imagealttext: |Heavy Metal Detox Bowl|Heavy Metal Detox Smoothie
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• 2 bananas
  • 2 cups wild blueberries OR 2 tbs of wild blueberry powder (Buy Here)
  • 1 cup of fresh cilantro OR 1 dropper full of cilantro tincture (Buy Here)
  • 1 cup orange juice
  • 1 tsp barley grass juice powder (Buy Here)
  • 1 tsp spirulina (Buy Here)
  • 1 tbs of Altantic dulse flakes (Buy Here)
  • Optional: water to blend
node.accordion_1_accordion_body: In a high speed blender, blend all ingredients until smooth. If a thinner consistency is desired, add up to 1 cup of water. Enjoy!

node.content:
Build your own modern industrial picnic table! The plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the picnic table are 34 1/4” W x 72” L x 32 1/2” H for the table section and 11 3/16" W x 72"L x 19 1/2"H for the benches.

Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck! 

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

*This project requires welding. If you’re not an experienced welder, I recommended hiring someone in your area.
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• 3 - 24’ 1/8” Square Steel Tube
  • 10 - 2” x 6” x 8’ Pine Boards
  • 1 - #10 x 21/2” Flat Head Phillips Sheet Metal Screw (50ct)
  • 1 - 9/64” Drill Bit
  • Flat Black Spray Paint
  • Wood Stain
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Cut all the square steel pipe to the specified dimensions in the cut list. Then, weld in the following order: tabletop, bench supports & legs, table base support. Make sure all pieces are square. Once welded, grind down the flux to have a smooth appearance. Paint the entire metal frame of the picnic table to prevent rusting.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions. Apply the desired stain to each board before attaching to the metal frame. To attach the boards to the frame, first pre-drill each screw hole with a 9/64” drill bit. Remember to let the bit do the work and don’t force it too much to prevent breaking the bit. As you pre-drill each board, follow by attaching with the 2 1/2” screws. There should be about a 1/4” gap between each board.

node.title: Foldable Cornhole Boards
node.content:
Build your own cornhole boards that fold into a lightweight portable carrying case. The plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the cornhole boards are the regulation 24"x48".

Helpful tips: Always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always pre-drill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
Don't have a specific tool? Click the item below to purchase it from Amazon.
  • Wood Glue
  • Tape Measure
  • Speed Square
  • Pencil
  • Safety Glasses
  • Ear Protection
  • Kreg Jig
  • Miter Saw or Circular Saw
  • 1/2” Paddle or Drill Bit
  • 1/8” Drill Bit
  • Hammer or Finish Nailer
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Lift off Hinge
  • Latch
  • 1 1/4” Kregg Screws
  • 1/2” Finish Nails
  • 2 - 1/2” x 2” Carriage Bolt
  • 2 - 1/2” Hex Nut
  • 3’ - 1/2” Rope
  • Corn Hole Bags
  • Gulf Tees
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Start by cutting the 1/4” plywood to the specified dimensions for the board surface. Use a 6” hole saw to cut out the center hole. Make sure the hole is positioned 9” down by 24” over. Repeat for other board.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Cut all the boards to the specified dimensions. The angle for the legs should be cut at 30 degrees and use a jigsaw to curve the opposite end. Then, drill 1/2” holes with the paddle bit in the legs and sideboards for the bolts. Next, in all of the 22 1/2” boards, pre-drill the holes for the Kregg Screws. The black rectangles in the drawing below indicated the pre-drilled holes for the Kregg screws. Finally, in one of the 22 1/2” boards, drill 21 holes, 3/4” apart for the peg scoreboard. Repeat for other board.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Assemble all the parts. Start with the outside boards. Be sure to use wood glue on all joints and make sure all Kregg screws are assembled from the inside. Also, the scoreboard must be assembled on the same end with the legs. Once the outside boards are screwed together, attach the inner supports. Finally, glue and nail on the surface board. Repeat for other board.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Attached all hardware. Start with the legs. Use the carriage bolt and hex nut to attach the legs. Tighten the bolt enough to allow the legs to swing. Next, place each cornhole board on top of one another with the board surface facing out. Attach the hinges and latches. Then, cut the rope into equal lengths and thread through each hole. Tie a knot on each end to prevent the rope from pulling through. Finally, paint the boards to your desired color or find vinyl wrap. Enjoy!

Repeat for other board.

,

Assemble all the parts. Start with the outside boards. Be sure to use wood glue on all joints and make sure all Kregg screws are assembled from the inside. Also, the scoreboard must be assembled on the same end with the legs. Once the outside boards are screwed together, attach the inner supports. Finally, glue and nail on the surface board. Repeat for other board.

,

Attached all hardware. Start with the legs. Use the carriage bolt and hex nut to attach the legs. Tighten the bolt enough to allow the legs to swing. Next, place each cornhole board on top of one another with the board surface facing out. Attach the hinges and latches. Then, cut the rope into equal lengths and thread through each hole. Tie a knot on each end to prevent the rope from pulling through. Finally, paint the boards to your desired color or find vinyl wrap. Enjoy!

node.title: Large Farmhouse Mirror
node.content:
Build your own large farmhouse mirror from IKEA Minde mirrors for under $75! Follow easy step-by-step plans that include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions. The overall dimensions of the mirror are 54 1/4" x 54 1/4".

This entire project was constructed from pallet boards. Before beginning this build, break down a few pallets and set aside the lumber. Remember, always work on a clean level surface, free of imperfections or debris. Always use straight boards. Check for square after each step. Always predrill holes before attaching with screws. Use glue with finish nails for a stronger hold. Wipe excess glue off bare wood for stained projects, as dried glue will not take stain. Be safe, have fun, and ask for help if you need it. Good luck!

Also, follow me on Pinterest or Instagram to get the first look at what I am working on next.

node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Cut all boards to the specified dimensions in the cut list. Then, use the Kregg jigg and pre-drill the screw holes in the top and bottom boards. The cylindrical shapes on the drawing below indicate the pre-drilled hole locations. Next, use the 1 1/4” Kregg screws and attach each board. Remember to use wood glue on all joints and wipe off any excess.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Attached the mirror slates. Make sure all the pieces fit nice and snug, then use wood glue to secure each slate in place. Wait for the wood glue to dry before moving onto the next step.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Finish the frame with a paint or stain of your choice. Be sure to paint/stain the back of the mirror frame, so that no unfinished wood reflects through the joint in the front. Add the front decorative hardware (optional). Attached the retainer clips evenly about 1 1/4” from the inside back edge. The mirrors will be inserted vertically. The center mirror will have 4 retainer chips, whereas the outside mirrors should have 6 each. Finally, add a 3/4” screw about 12” down from each side. Do not drive the screw in too far or it will pop out in the front. These screws will be used to attached the picture hanging wire. Cut the wire to a length so that it hides behind the mirror while hanging. Wrap the wire around each screw. Hang and enjoy!

node.title: How to Paint Cabinets
node.imagealttext: Renovated RV Kitchen|
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• Degreaser
  • 220 Grit Sand Paper
  • Caulk
  • Primer
  • Paint
  • Flood Floetrol
  • Cabinet Bumpers
  • Poly
Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Cabinet & Trim Enamel
  • Benjamin Moore Advance
  • Sherwin Williams Emerald
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Foam Roller
  • Paint Brush
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Remove all the doors and hardware. It's easier to clean, sand, and paint without having to cut around the hardware.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Degrease. Use a good degreaser and wipe down all the cabinets. You want to remove any oily residue to ensure proper paint adhesion.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Sand. Use 220 grit sandpaper and sand all parts of the cabinets. This step is very important and should never be skipped. Sanding allows the primer/paint to adhere properly and will prevent any chips in the future.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Caulk. If you have any small gaps on the front of the door panels, use a little caulk to fill the space. Wipe any excess off. Make sure you use a paintable caulk.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Learn how to paint cabinets in your RV or camper by following easy step-by-step instructions, find links to all recommended paint products, and more.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Prime. Use a good primer like Gripper, which can be found at Home Depot or Kilz Adhesion. Do one coat of primer on all parts of the cabinets. Wait 24-48 hours, then lightly sand and wipe down with a damp cloth to remove any debris before applying your first coat of paint.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content:
Paint. Get good quality paint. At least an eggshell or satin finish is recommended.  Use a brush to get in the corners of the cabinet doors and use a foam roller to smooth the finish and remove brush strokes. You could also use a paint spray for a flawless finish. I recommend the Graco Magnum paint sprayer. Let your first coat dry for about 24-48 hours, then apply a second coat in the same manner. Again, wait 24-48 hours and once the second coat is dry. Be sure to lightly sand and wipe down between the coats.

Tip: To hide any brush strokes, roller marks, or even to get a spray finish smooth as glass, I highly recommend using Flood Floetrol. Mix 8oz in 1 gallon of paint. Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Cabinet & Trim Enamel
  • Benjamin Moore Advance
  • Sherwin Williams Emerald
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)
node.instructions_6_instructions_content: Poly. This step is optional, but it will seal your cabinets to prevent chipping. I like a matte water based polyurethane.
node.instructions_7_instructions_content: Put hardware and doors back on. Be sure to use bumpers on the corners of the doors and drawers, so the paint doesn’t stick together. Be careful with the freshly painted cabinets for about 2 weeks. They take awhile to fully cure and have a durable finish.

• Degreaser
  • 220 Grit Sand Paper
  • Caulk
  • Primer
  • Paint
  • Flood Floetrol
  • Cabinet Bumpers
  • Poly
Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Cabinet & Trim Enamel
  • Benjamin Moore Advance
  • Sherwin Williams Emerald
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)
,
  • Foam Roller
  • Paint Brush
node.instructions_instructions_content:
Remove all the doors and hardware. It's easier to clean, sand, and paint without having to cut around the hardware.

,

Degrease. Use a good degreaser and wipe down all the cabinets. You want to remove any oily residue to ensure proper paint adhesion.

,

Sand. Use 220 grit sandpaper and sand all parts of the cabinets. This step is very important and should never be skipped. Sanding allows the primer/paint to adhere properly and will prevent any chips in the future.

,Caulk. If you have any small gaps on the front of the door panels, use a little caulk to fill the space. Wipe any excess off. Make sure you use a paintable caulk.,

Prime. Use a good primer like Gripper, which can be found at Home Depot or Kilz Adhesion. Do one coat of primer on all parts of the cabinets. Wait 24-48 hours, then lightly sand and wipe down with a damp cloth to remove any debris before applying your first coat of paint.

,

Paint. Get good quality paint. At least an eggshell or satin finish is recommended.  Use a brush to get in the corners of the cabinet doors and use a foam roller to smooth the finish and remove brush strokes. You could also use a paint spray for a flawless finish. I recommend the Graco Magnum paint sprayer. Let your first coat dry for about 24-48 hours, then apply a second coat in the same manner. Again, wait 24-48 hours and once the second coat is dry. Be sure to lightly sand and wipe down between the coats.

Tip: To hide any brush strokes, roller marks, or even to get a spray finish smooth as glass, I highly recommend using Flood Floetrol. Mix 8oz in 1 gallon of paint. Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Cabinet & Trim Enamel
  • Benjamin Moore Advance
  • Sherwin Williams Emerald
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)
,

Poly. This step is optional, but it will seal your cabinets to prevent chipping. I like a matte water based polyurethane.

,

Put hardware and doors back on. Be sure to use bumpers on the corners of the doors and drawers, so the paint doesn’t stick together. Be careful with the freshly painted cabinets for about 2 weeks. They take awhile to fully cure and have a durable finish.

node.title: How to Install Camper Flooring
node.content:
Are you beginning a camper renovation and not sure what flooring to go with? If you’ve done hours of research like me, you’ll find out that there is no right answer. Some go with laminate, vinyl, tile, or even hardwood. So let me tell you what I decided to go with and why.

I chose TrafficMASTER Luxury Vinyl Gripstrip Planks for these reasons.

  1. It’s 100% Waterproof. In my opinion, you need something 100% waterproof because having water come inside your camper is inevitable. Even if it’s just a slight mist that blows through the screen door during a summer rainstorm.
  2. It’s lightweight. Out of all the vinyl plank flooring on the market, this brand is the most lightweight you can find. In a camper renovation, you should always be aware of the weight and be sure to stay under the G.A.W.R (Gross Axle Weight Rating) for safety reasons.
  3. It’s durable. I have vinyl plank in my home with two dogs and after 5 years, the floor still looks brand new; even when they get the “zoomies“ and run as fast as they can, but just slip on the floor with their nails.
  4. It can be glued. With the flex of a camper while being towed, as well as temperature fluctuations, the flooring should really be glued down to prevent buckling, separating, and cracking. The glue will give it a secure hold. Plus it helps alleviate the hollow sound as you walk on it.
  5. It can be found at Home Depot. Let’s face it, everyone has a Home Depot relatively close. You can’t beat the convenience of just running to Home Depot and picking up the flooring, or having it shipped right to your home. Most custom flooring stores will take 3-4 weeks to have the product ordered and ready for pickup.

Those are all the reasons for my flooring choice, but let me shed some light why I did not go with the other options.

  • Click-Lock Luxury Vinyl Planks: Most options are pretty thick and heavy. Plus if you winterized your camper, the cold weather makes the click-lock seams brittle and you could risk them breaking.
  • Laminate: It’s not waterproof. Any water exposure will cause it to swell.
  • Tile: With the flex of the camper while towing it’s susceptible to cracking
  • Hardwood: It’s heavy, prone to scratches, and not waterproof.
  • Vinyl Sheet: This is actually a great option to consider. The only reason I swayed from it was that it’s harder to install as an individual DIY’er, takes 3-4 weeks to be ordered, and I fear the slideout tearing it since it’s not as durable as the vinyl planks.

In the end, I hope this was valuable information and helps you chose the best flooring option for your camper. I have provided easy step-by-step instructions for the flooring installation below.

Also, follow along with my camper renovation on instagram @thehappyglamperco
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• TrafficMASTER Luxury Vinyl Planks
  • Flooring Adhesive
  • Flooring Roller
  • Behr DeckOver Paint (optional)
*9 cases of flooring and 2 gallons of flooring glue are needed for a 30' camper
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• 1/16" Notched Trowel
  • Utility knife
  • T-Square
  • Pencil
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Make sure the subfloor is fully prepped. All staples removed or hammered in, any water damage repaired, and uneven seams sanded down. If your subfloors are flaking, have glue remnants, or has various cracks and gaps – I recommend applying a coat of Behr DeckOver Paint to unify the surface.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Start in the left-hand corner of your camper that has a slideout or the longest run without obstacles. Apply a thin layer of flooring adhesive with a 1/16" notched trowel. Be sure to hold the trowel at a 45-degree angle. You can spread the flooring adhesive as you go for a more permanent hold or apply sections and let it dry for a removable hold.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Lay your first plank of flooring and keep a 1/4” gap between the wall and flooring. When applying each plank thereafter, hold at a 45-degree angle, place the left corner in first and adhere the plank.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Use a flooring roller to ensure proper adhesion.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Find out what the best type of flooring you should put in your RV or camper. Follow easy step-by-step instructions, find links to all recommended flooring products, and more.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: To start another row, be sure to alternate the seams. I recommended cutting the second-row starting plank in half. To cut a plank, use a T-square, score with a utility knife, and bend the plank at the score line till it breaks. Use the razor to cut through the remaining plank layer.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Repeat this process until complete. Then finish off by adding PVC molding at the base of the wall and flooring.
node.accordion_2_accordion_body:
How do you get the flooring underneath the slideout?

To run the flooring underneath a slideout you can do it one of two ways. Option 1: Extend the slide fully. Remove any gaskets that run along the bottom of the slide opening. Next, with bottle jacks and a couple of 2x4's, jack up the slide box a few inches to give you space to slide the new flooring in. Finally, install the new flooring, lower the jacks, and put the gasket back on. If your camper has/needs additional wear bars, I recommend this one: https://store.lci1.com/wear-bar-10ft-117478.html Option 2: Use a crowbar or hammer to pry up the edge of the subfloor enough that you can slide a block of wood underneath. This way, you have enough room to slide the flooring under the slide subfloor. Go as far back with the flooring as you can without pushing past the exterior seal/wiper. Important: When jacking the slide box up or prying on the subfloor, be mindful of the top as there are only a few inches of space between the top and camper opening.

How did you trim the front edge of the slideout?

Since my slideout was angled, I cut strips of the flooring and glued/screwed them to the front edge with 1/4" screws. Then, I used caulk to fill the gap between the main slideout flooring and the front strip.

Another method would be to rip a 1"x3" board at a 12.5-degree angle, then attach it to the angled edge with wood glue and 1/2" finish nails. This will make the edge square, and then you can add stair nose trim to give you the finished look.

How do you keep the slideout from scratching the flooring?

My model only had two 12" wear bars on each end of the slideout, so I ran an additional 10' wear bar underneath the entire slideout for an extra lift when retracting in. Also, I definitely recommend getting a set or two of Slide-Out Slickers for the corners and center of the slideout. The corners typically cause the most wear so that the slickers will prevent any contact with your flooring.

  • Flooring Adhesive
  • Flooring Roller
  • Behr DeckOver Paint (optional)

node.title: How to make DIY Roll-up Curtains
node.content: Follow these easy step-by-step instructions to make your own roll-up curtains! The average cost per curtain comes out to $15. That's a huge savings for your RV renovation, plus they are lightweight and fashionable. Also, be sure to follow me on Instagram to see what else I'm up to.
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• 1 - 9' x 12' Drop Cloth
  • 18 - 1/2 x 48" Wooden Dowel
  • 3 - 1" x 72" Leather Strap
  • 1 pack - 1" Antique Copper Lobster Clasps
  • 1 pack - 1" Antique Copper D Rings
  • 2 packs - 1/2" Copper Pipe Straps
  • 1 pack - 1" Screws
  • Beige Thread
  • Brown Thread
  • 1 pack - Headless Screws (optional)
*Quantities make 9 curtains for an RV.
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Sewing Machine
  • Iron
  • Cutting Mat
  • Exacto Knife or Fabric Scissors
  • Aluminum Yard Stick
  • Fabric Tape Measure
  • Hot Glue Gun
  • Fine Finish Hand Saw
  • Wood Glue (optional)
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: First, measure your window. Add 4" to the width and 7" to the height and cut the fabric with an Exacto knife. Be sure to use a straight edge and make sure the material is square.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Starting with the sides, fold the fabric over 1" and iron float.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Sew each of the sides with the zig-zag stitch.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Fold over the top and bottom edges over 1" and sew with the zig-zag stitch. Tip: Make sure all the seams are folded and sewn from the same side.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Follow these easy step-by-step instructions to make your own roll-up curtains for your camper or RV. The average cost per curtain comes out to $15.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Cut the strap material with scissors or an Exacto knife to 9".
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Add a D ring to one side and fold over 1". Sew the material with a straight stitch. Repeat on the other side with the lobster clasp. Be sure to go as slow as possible for the needle to penetrate both layers of leather. You could also opt to use metal rivets in place of sewing. NOTE: If your sewing machine won't puncture through the leather, soak it in water to soften up the leather. You can also use the handwheel on your sewing machine to manually create the stitch.
node.accordion_2_accordion_body:
Curtain Panel
  1. Measure the window width and height from the outside of the trim
  2. Cut the material to size
    1. Width: Window width + 4"
    2. Height: Window height + 7"
  3. Sewed material
    1. Width: Window width + 2"
    2. Height: Window height + 5"
Straps
  1. Cut material 9" long
  2. Fold each end over 1" with a lobster clasp and D ring
Dowels
  1. Cut the dowel 4" longer than the sewed material width
node.instructions_6_instructions_content: Cut your dowels to size. Make sure the dowel is 4" larger than the sewn material. Insert the dowel into the curtain panel. Next, measure over 4" from the end of the fabric and hot glue the strap to the wooden dowel inside the curtain panel.
node.instructions_7_instructions_content: Note: If you have a window larger than 48", use the headless screws to join two dowels. Pre-drill a hole slightly smaller than the size of the headless screw, add wood glue on both ends, insert the screw, and attach the two ends.
node.instructions_8_instructions_content: Place the copper tube straps on the dowel and measure up 4" from the top of your window. Use 1" screws to attach the tube straps to the wall. Enjoy! <ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display: block; text-align: center;" data-ad-layout="in-article" data-ad-format="fluid" data-ad-client="ca-pub-3133257559155527" data-ad-slot="1168701770"></ins>
node.accordion_accordion_body:
• 1 - 9' x 12' Drop Cloth
  • 18 - 1/2 x 48" Wooden Dowel
  • 3 - 1" x 72" Leather Strap
  • 1 pack - 1" Antique Copper Lobster Clasps
  • 1 pack - 1" Antique Copper D Rings
  • 2 packs - 1/2" Copper Pipe Straps
  • 1 pack - 1" Screws
  • Beige Thread
  • Brown Thread
  • 1 pack - Headless Screws (optional)
*Quantities make 9 curtains for an RV.,
  • Sewing Machine
  • Iron
  • Cutting Mat
  • Exacto Knife or Fabric Scissors
  • Aluminum Yard Stick
  • Fabric Tape Measure
  • Hot Glue Gun
  • Fine Finish Hand Saw
  • Wood Glue (optional)
,Curtain Panel
  1. Measure the window width and height from the outside of the trim
  2. Cut the material to size
    1. Width: Window width + 4"
    2. Height: Window height + 7"
  3. Sewed material
    1. Width: Window width + 2"
    2. Height: Window height + 5"
Straps
  1. Cut material 9" long
  2. Fold each end over 1" with a lobster clasp and D ring
Dowels
  1. Cut the dowel 4" longer than the sewed material width
node.instructions_instructions_content: First, measure your window. Add 4" to the width and 7" to the height and cut the fabric with an Exacto knife. Be sure to use a straight edge and make sure the material is square.,Starting with the sides, fold the fabric over 1" and iron float.,Sew each of the sides with the zig-zag stitch.,Fold over the top and bottom edges over 1" and sew with the zig-zag stitch. Tip: Make sure all the seams are folded and sewn from the same side.,Cut the strap material with scissors or an Exacto knife to 9".,Add a D ring to one side and fold over 1". Sew the material with a straight stitch. Repeat on the other side with the lobster clasp. Be sure to go as slow as possible for the needle to penetrate both layers of leather. You could also opt to use metal rivets in place of sewing. NOTE: If your sewing machine won't puncture through the leather, soak it in water to soften up the leather. You can also use the handwheel on your sewing machine to manually create the stitch.,Cut your dowels to size. Make sure the dowel is 4" larger than the sewn material. Insert the dowel into the curtain panel. Next, measure over 4" from the end of the fabric and hot glue the strap to the wooden dowel inside the curtain panel.,Note: If you have a window larger than 48", use the headless screws to join two dowels. Pre-drill a hole slightly smaller than the size of the headless screw, add wood glue on both ends, insert the screw, and attach the two ends.,Place the copper tube straps on the dowel and measure up 4" from the top of your window. Use 1" screws to attach the tube straps to the wall. Enjoy!

node.title: How to Repair Water Damage on Slideout Floors
node.content: Follow these step-by-step instructions on how to repair your slideout floors from water damage. Since all slideouts are built differently, the instructions below are for models that have wear bars.
node.imagealttext: |Slideout Water Damage Repair||Porter Cable Sander|Slideout Subfloor Angle|Hammering in Subfloor|Milwaukee Impact Driver and Kreg Jig||Removing Old Subfloor in a camper|Milwaukee Circular Saw|Milwaukee Circular Saw|Milwaukee Impact Driver|Wood Glue and Pocket Holes|Kreg Jig and Milwaukee Impact Driver|Milwaukee Circular Saw|Underneath Slideout|Camper Exterior Screws|Lag Bolt
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• Plywood
  • Wood Glue
  • 1 1/4" Pocket Screws
  • 2 1/2" Exterior Screws
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Pry Bar
  • Hammer
  • Circular Saw
  • Multitool
  • Kreg Jig
  • Staple Gun
  • Sander
  • Shop Vac
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Remove any lag bolts and screws that may be holding in the water damaged section of the subfloor. Only remove the screws/bolts from the area you will be replacing. Screws can be found on the exterior edge as well as underneath the slideout.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Set your circular saw blade to the depth of the subfloor. (In my case, it was 3/4"). Then, mark a line with a straight edge and cut along it with the circular saw. For any areas that the circular saw blade can't reach, use a multitool. Important: Make sure your line is square, and your cut is clean. This is important because the new subfloor piece will need to butt up against the original floor without any gaps. Also, be careful not to cut any wires that run through the subfloor and into the walls.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: With a pry bar or hammer, pry up the water damaged section of the subfloor. Try to keep the black underbelly cover intact. Clean up any debris with a shop vac.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Measure and cut a new piece of plywood that will fit in the place of the water damaged section. Then, with a Kreg Jig – drill pocket holes every 4". Use these instructions to set the correct depth of your jig. If you have wires that run through the floor into the walls, be sure to notch out a small rectangle for them. Remember: Make sure the plywood extends underneath the wall studs, and your cuts are clean and square.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Follow step-by-step instructions on how to properly repair water damage on a RV slideout floor.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Slide the new piece of plywood in and make sure the underbelly is pulled tight. Once the plywood is in, apply a generous amount of wood glue down the seam. Then, use pocket screws to attach the new plywood to the original subfloor. Make sure the two pieces are flush. Note: If you have trouble sliding the piece in place, use a block of wood and hammer it in. You also might need to pry up the edge of the wall for extra clearance.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Once the wood glue is dry, sand down the seam with 80 grit sandpaper to ensure a smooth transition between the two plywood pieces. Tip: If you have an angled edge on the front of your slideout floor, rip down a 1x3 at 12.5º to make the edge square. Then, attach with wood glue and 3/4" finish nails at a 45º angle.
node.instructions_6_instructions_content: From underneath the slideout, add 2 1/2" exterior screws into the new plywood and wall studs. Then, replace any removed lag bolts. Finally, staple the underbelly back into place and use underbelly tape to repair any areas that you may have cut. Important: Make sure the screws are countersunk so that there is no risk of the screw heads scratching your floor when the slideout is retracted in.
node.etsylinkdescription: *The plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions.
node.accordion_accordion_body:
• Plywood
  • Wood Glue
  • 1 1/4" Pocket Screws
  • 2 1/2" Exterior Screws
,
  • Pry Bar
  • Hammer
  • Circular Saw
  • Multitool
  • Kreg Jig
  • Staple Gun
  • Sander
  • Shop Vac

node.title: How to Winterize Your RV
node.content: Winterizing your RV is crucial if you're in an area that experiences below-freezing temperatures. If the temperatures are going to go below freezing for more than 24hrs, then you will need to winterize your RV to prevent any damage to the plumbing system. Below is a step-by-step guide to complete the winterizing basics on your own!
node.imagealttext: Camper Remodel|||||||
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• Winterizing Kit
OR
  • 3 gallons of RV antifreeze
  • Hand Pump
  • Blow Out Plug
  • Mini Dehumidifier
More
  • Hot Water Tank Rinsing Wand
  • Hot Water Tank Bypass Valve
  • Water Pump Converter Kit (optional)
  • Irish Spring Soap
node.accordion_1_accordion_body: • Compressor
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Clean the entire interior. Make sure all trash is removed, vacuum up any/all food crumbs, and wipe down all surfaces. Stove: Clean all food and crumbs from the stovetop and oven. Fridge: Make sure the fridge is defrosted and wipe down the interior of any water and food. Then, prop the doors open while in storage to prevent any mold.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Disconnect your RV. Disconnect the water source, turn off all power, and shut off your propane tanks.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content:
Bypass the water heater. Turn the water heater bypass valve to closed. Most RV’s already have a water heater bypass valve installed and you can locate this inside near the water heater. Note: If you do not have a bypass valve, I recommend installing one or you’ll need an additional 6 to 10 gallons of antifreeze.

Note: If you have a water filtration unit in your RV, be sure to bypass that as well.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Drain/blow out the lines. Open all faucets in your entire RV and let the water drain out. Next, connect the blowout plug to the city water inlet and use a compressor at 30psi to force out all the remaining water from the lines. Once the lines are empty, close all the faucets.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Follow an easy step-by-step guide on how to winterize your camper to prevent any damage to the plumbing system.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Empty the black and grey tanks. Once the tanks are completely drained, make sure the valves are shut.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content:
Empty the freshwater tank. There is a valve on the bottom of the freshwater tank. Just open it up and let the tank drain. Leave the value open till spring.

Note: If you open the valve and water does not flow out (if the tank has water), it could be clogged. Just take a hose and run water through the valve. It will clear the blockage.
node.instructions_6_instructions_content:
Drain the water heater. Before doing this, make sure the water heater and the water pump are turned off and the water is completely cool. Open up the water heater panel from the outside and remove the drain plug. Once all the water has drained, flush out any sediment using a water heater tank rinsing wand to remove any sediment. Leave the drain plug open until spring.

Note: If you don't have a hot water bypass valve, then you'll need to put the drain plug back in because the hot water heater will need to be filled with antifreeze.
node.instructions_7_instructions_content:
Fill the plumbing system with antifreeze. There are two ways to do this:

  1. With the water pump via a pump converter kit. This kit allows you to pump antifreeze through the lines quickly and easily via your water pump. Some RV's already have them installed from the factory, but if your model is not equipped with one, you can install it for relatively cheap. See it here.
  2. With a hand pump.

If you have a water pump converter kit installed:

  • Turn the valve to open and place the tube into a gallon of antifreeze.
  • Turn on the water pump
  • Go around to each faucet and turn on the hot water until you see the antifreeze come out. Once you see the antifreeze, close the faucet valve. Repeat this process for the cold water.
  • Flush your toilet until antifreeze appears as well.

If you have a hand pump:

  • Connect the hand pump to the city water inlet per the instructions.
  • Open the hot water of the highest faucet first (typically the kitchen sink). Pump antifreeze until you see it come out and close the faucet valve. Repeat this process for the cold water and all other faucets and toilets.
Now all the water lines are winterized! Note: If you have an ice maker or washing machine, follow the manufacturer user manual for instructions on winterizing those items.
node.instructions_8_instructions_content: Add antifreeze to each drain. Go around to each sink, shower, and toilet and pour about a 1/2 gallon of antifreeze down the drain. This will protect the sink traps and the black/grey tanks from freezing.
node.instructions_9_instructions_content: Remove all food, drinks, and toiletries. When temperatures drop below freezing, liquid items can freeze and burst, so you just want to make sure they are all removed. Also, any food items can attract rodents. Note: To keep rodents out, try placing bars of Irish Spring Soap under the sinks, in cabinets, and in general places around your RV. They say Irish Spring Soap deters mice and it's the only one they won't eat. I will post back on the results.
node.instructions_10_instructions_content: Close all windows and vents. Go around your RV and make sure all the roof vents and windows are securely shut.
node.instructions_11_instructions_content: Place mini dehumidifiers around your RV. Open the mini dehumidifier or moisture absorber and place it on a surface. It will remove dampness from the air and help prevent corrosion, mold, and mildew.
node.instructions_12_instructions_content: Inspect and clean the exterior. Go around the exterior and make sure all seals around the doors, windows, and corners look good. If they are cracked, you'll need to reseal them. See the steps here. Go on the roof and inspect the lap sealant to make sure it's not cracked as well. If you see cracks apply some more lap sealant to prevent roof water damage. Finally, wash the exterior of your RV.
node.etsylinkdescription: *The plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions.

OR
  • 3 gallons of RV antifreeze
  • Hand Pump
  • Blow Out Plug
  • Mini Dehumidifier
More
  • Hot Water Tank Rinsing Wand
  • Hot Water Tank Bypass Valve
  • Water Pump Converter Kit (optional)
  • Irish Spring Soap

If you have a water pump converter kit installed:

  • Turn the valve to open and place the tube into a gallon of antifreeze.
  • Turn on the water pump

  • Flush your toilet until antifreeze appears as well.

Also, any food items can attract rodents. Note: To keep rodents out, try placing bars of Irish Spring Soap under the sinks, in cabinets, and in general places around your RV. They say Irish Spring Soap deters mice and it's the only one they won't eat. I will post back on the results.,Close all windows and vents. Go around your RV and make sure all the roof vents and windows are securely shut.,Place mini dehumidifiers around your RV. Open the mini dehumidifier or moisture absorber and place it on a surface. It will remove dampness from the air and help prevent corrosion, mold, and mildew.,Inspect and clean the exterior. Go around the exterior and make sure all seals around the doors, windows, and corners look good. If they are cracked, you'll need to reseal them. See the steps here. Go on the roof and inspect the lap sealant to make sure it's not cracked as well. If you see cracks apply some more lap sealant to prevent roof water damage. Finally, wash the exterior of your RV.

node.title: How to Paint a Camper Exterior
node.content: Follow the step-by-step instructions below on how to paint your RV or camper exterior. Also, find links to all the recommended paint products.
node.imagealttext: Painting a camper|Camper Exterior Redo|Camper Exterior Redo|Camper Exterior Redo|Painting a Camper|Painting a camper|How to paint a camper|Painting a camper exterior
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• Dupli-Color Primer
  • Dupli-Color Base Color Paint
  • Dupli-Color Clear Coat
  • FrogTape Painters Tape
  • Masking Paper
  • Acetone or Goof Off
  • Scuff Pads
  • Sanding Block
  • Microfiber Cloth
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Paint Sprayer
  • Decal Remover Tool
node.instructions_0_instructions_content:
Wash your camper's exterior to remove any dirt/road grime. Also, be sure to remove all decals from areas that you plan to paint. Never paint over decals. I recommend using a decal remover tool to remove any decals easily. To remove decals:
  1. Use a heat gun to heat the decal so that you can pull off the vinyl by hand.
  2. Remove any remaining decal residue with a cloth and Goof Off.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Caulk. Make sure all the joints do not have any gaps or cracks in the caulk. If they do, be sure to re-seal them before you begin painting. Reference the steps on this post: How to Reseal an RV
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Tape/Mask off any areas that you do not want to be painted. Use the masking paper to block off larger areas from overspray.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Sand down all areas of the camper that you plan to paint. Use an 80 grit sanding block and lightly sand the exterior to create a smooth surface.
node._yoast_wpseo_focuskw: how to paint a travel trailer
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Learn how to paint a RV or camper exterior by following easy step-by-step instructions, find links to all recommended paint products, and more.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Wipe down the exterior with acetone and a microfiber cloth to remove any oily residue that might prevent good adhesion. Then, wipe the area down again with a damp microfiber cloth to ensure there is no dust.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Prime. Using a paint sprayer, apply one coat of primer. The primer is an important step to allow for proper adhesion. It also helps unify the surface and allows for good paint coverage. Remember: Never paint in direct sunlight or on windy days. Be careful not to stir up dust.
node.instructions_6_instructions_content: Paint. Using a paint sprayer, apply one coat of paint. Try to keep a wet edge and go in smooth horizontal movements with the paint sprayer.
node.instructions_7_instructions_content: Scuff. Allow the paint to dry, then lightly scuff the painted surface with a scuff pad. Then, wipe down the entire surface again with a clean damp cloth to remove any dust particles.
node.instructions_8_instructions_content: Recoat. Apply another coat of paint. If the paint still looks uneven after drying, scuff once again and apply another coat of paint.
node.instructions_9_instructions_content: Clearcoat. Using a paint sprayer, apply one coat of clear coat. The clear coat will give your paint that finished look and protect the paint from chipping and fading.
node.instructions_10_instructions_content: Remove all painter's tape and masking paper. Once the paint has fully cured according to the Dupli-color instructions, buff the surface to enhance the paint's look. Enjoy!

node.title: How to Install a RV Keyless Door Lock
node.content:
If you're tired of struggling with keys to lock/unlock your camper, I highly recommend this latch.it RV Keyless Entry Lock. The entire installation process took about 5 minutes and fit right into the existing door handle cutout. Some nice features of the lock are:

  • It's 100% metal
  • Has a backlit keypad for easy entry at night
  • You can enter your trailer by 3 various methods: keypad, key-fob, or mechanical key
  • The key fobs work up to 80 feet away
  • The lock will fit most trailers with an opening of 3.75" x 2.75" x 1.5"
  • It's a USA Owned Family Business!
Buy Here
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• 1 - RV Door Lock
  • 2 - Wireless Key Fob Controllers
  • 1 - Mounting Hardware Set
  • 1 - Easy-to-Install User Manual
  • 4 - AA Batteries
  • 2 - Mechanical Keys
  • Bonus #1: Door Lock Protection Gasket
  • Bonus #2: Long Screwdriver
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Remove the existing door handle by unscrewing the 4 screws on the inside of the door. Then, remove the two screws from the side strike plate. The handle will pull right out.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Insert the batteries into the new latch.it Keyless Entry Lock. Then, carefully slide the front face into the cutout, pull the wires through, and attach the new strike plate. Connect the wire harness on each lock face.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Attach the two lock faces with the 4 long screws. Be sure not to pinch any wires. Program your key fob and keypad based on the user's manual and you're all set!
node.etsylinkdescription: *The plans include a material cut list, a list of necessary tools & hardware, assembly directions, and dimensions.
node.accordion_accordion_body:
• 1 - RV Door Lock
  • 2 - Wireless Key Fob Controllers
  • 1 - Mounting Hardware Set
  • 1 - Easy-to-Install User Manual
  • 4 - AA Batteries
  • 2 - Mechanical Keys
  • Bonus #1: Door Lock Protection Gasket
  • Bonus #2: Long Screwdriver
node.instructions_instructions_content: Remove the existing door handle by unscrewing the 4 screws on the inside of the door. Then, remove the two screws from the side strike plate. The handle will pull right out.,Insert the batteries into the new latch.it Keyless Entry Lock. Then, carefully slide the front face into the cutout, pull the wires through, and attach the new strike plate. Connect the wire harness on each lock face.,Attach the two lock faces with the 4 long screws. Be sure not to pinch any wires. Program your key fob and keypad based on the user's manual and you're all set!

node.title: How to Paint RV Walls
node.content:
Looking to paint your RV, but don't know where to start? Below I've outlined all the steps on how to paint your RV walls successfully. Also, check out my expense report to see how much it cost me to paint a 30' trailer. The total includes paint for the walls and cabinets.

Breakdown of the amount of paint I used for a 30' trailer.

  • 3 gallons of Gripper Primer or Kilz Adhesion Primer
  • 4 gallons of white (Frost by Behr)
  • 1 gallon of green (Pewter Green by Sherwin Williams)
  • 1 gallon of black (Broadway by Behr)

Other Resources:

  • Expense Report
  • How to Paint Cabinets
node.imagealttext: RV Renovation Painted Walls|RV Renovation|Camper Remodel|Painting a camper|Painting the interior of a camper|How to paint camper walls|Painting RV walls|Sharpie Shiplap
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• PPG Gripper Primer or Kilz Adhesion Primer
  • Paint
  • 1 quart of Flood Floetrol
Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Marquee
  • Benjamin Moore Regal Select
  • Sherwin Williams Duration
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• TSP
  • 3/8" Nap Rollers
  • Angled Paint Brush
  • Paint Tray
  • Frogtape Painter's Tape
  • Dap Extreme Stretch Caulk
  • DAP Wood Filler
  • Razor Blade
  • Paint Sprayer (optional)
node.instructions_0_instructions_content:
Remove any blinds, valances, or other items screwed to the walls. It's easier to paint without having to cut around items on the walls. Also, be sure to remove any wallpaper borders. To remove the wallpaper borders, use a heat gun and heat the border for easy removal. Use acetone to remove any remaining adhesive.

Please note: Do not try to remove the full wallpaper from the plywood wall panels. It adheres really well, and you risk damaging the plywood.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Patch. Fill in any old screw holes or dings with DAP wood filler. If the surface is raised around the screw hole, first use a razor blade to scrape the raised material. Then, apply the wood filler, and once it's dry, sand with 220 grit sandpaper. You only need to sand areas of the walls you've patched—no need to sand the walls entirely.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Degrease. Use TSP and wipe down all the walls. You want to remove any oily residue to ensure proper paint adhesion.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Caulk. If you have any small gaps along the ceiling and walls, use Dap Extreme Stretch Caulk to fill the gap. Wipe any excess off. Important: You'll want to use a paintable caulk and has a lot of flexibility since campers flex while going down the road.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Learn how to paint your interior RV or camper walls by following easy step-by-step instructions, find links to all recommended paint products, and more.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Tape. With Frogtape painters tape, tape off any areas that you don't want to get paint on, like switches, outlets, and window frames. You can also use 3M masking film to mask off larger areas. Note: I do recommend Frogtape because it gives you cleaner edges with little to no paint bleed.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content:
Prime. Use a good primer like Gripper, which can be found at Home Depot or Kilz Adhesion. Do 1-2 coats of primer on all the walls that you will be applying color. Wait 24-48 hours before applying your first coat of paint. Once everything is primed, go through a putty any missed holes and caulk any visible gaps.

Important: Do not skip priming! This step is important so that your paint doesn't flake or scratch off in time.
node.instructions_6_instructions_content:
Paint. Get good quality paint. At least an eggshell or satin finish is recommended.  Use a brush to get in the corners of the walls and use 3/8" nap rollers to apply most of the paint. You could also use a paint spray for a flawless finish. I recommend the Graco Magnum paint sprayer. Let your first coat dry for about 24-48 hours, then apply a second coat in the same manner. Again, wait 24-48 hours, and once the second coat is dry, be sure to lightly sand and wipe down between the coats.

Tip: To hide any brush strokes, roller marks, or even to get a spray finish smooth as glass, I highly recommend using Flood Floetrol. Mix 8oz in 1 gallon of paint. Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Marquee
  • Benjamin Moore Regal Select
  • Sherwin Williams Duration
node.instructions_7_instructions_content: Remove any painter's tape and put everything back on the walls. Be careful with the freshly painted walls for about 2 weeks. They take a while to cure and have a durable finish fully. <ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display: block; text-align: center;" data-ad-layout="in-article" data-ad-format="fluid" data-ad-client="ca-pub-3133257559155527" data-ad-slot="1168701770"></ins>

  • Paint
  • 1 quart of Flood Floetrol
Paint recommendations:
  • Behr Marquee
  • Benjamin Moore Regal Select
  • Sherwin Williams Duration
  • Behr Ultra Scuff Defense (This is a flat finish and I've had great results with durability)

,Remove any painter's tape and put everything back on the walls. Be careful with the freshly painted walls for about 2 weeks. They take a while to cure and have a durable finish fully.

node.title: How to make a DIY Letter Ledge
node.imagealttext: DIY Letter Ledge|Letter Ledge DIY|DIY Letter Ledge|DIY Letter Ledge|DIY Letter Ledge|DIY Letter Ledge|DIY Letter Ledge
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
Item Description Quantity
11" x 14" .093" Acrylic Sheet Order here 3
1" x 3" x 8" Pine Board Order here 1
12" x 12" Vinyl Sheets Order here 1 pack
1 1/4” 18 Gauge Brad Nails Order here 1 pack
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Cricut Explore Air
  • Table Saw
  • Miter Saw
  • 220 Grit Sand Paper
  • 18 Gauge Finish Nailer
node.instructions_0_instructions_content:
Cut the 1x3 board to your desired length for each letter ledge row. Next, set the height of your table saw blade to 1". Then, set the width of the glide rail to 3/8". Pass the 1x3 through the table saw blade to create a 1" deep channel. Finish/Stain as desired. My favorite finish combination:
  1. Minwax Pre-Stain Conditioner
  2. Minwax Early American
  3. Minwax Weathered Oak
  4. Water-Based Poly
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Set the height of your table saw blade to 1/4". Then, set the width of the glide rail to your desired letter card length. I ripped an 11x14 acrylic sheet into 10 - 2.75" x 5 1/5" cards, so I set the glide rail at 5 1/2". Rip down the acrylic sheet into two equal lengths. Then, use the miter saw to cut the width of each letter card. Sand any rough edges down with 220 grit sandpaper and removed the acrylic sheet protector. *Note: Always account for the 1/8" blade thickness. Also, when cutting the acrylic sheet, be sure to go as slow as possible to prevent chipping.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Use your Cricut or vinyl cutter to cut out letters in the vinyl sheets. I used the font GoBold and made the letters each 3" in height. Once your letters are cut, apply them to each letter card. Make sure the letter card is free from debris, and account for 1" that will be hidden by the wooden letter ledge row. It also helps to lay a grid underneath the letter card surface to help visually align all the letters the same.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Finally, insert your letter cards into the letter ledge row and figure out the spacing for each row. Use a finish nailer to tack each row onto your wall. Be sure to nail the bottom of the board only. You don't want to nail through any of your cards. Enjoy!

node.title: How to Reseal an RV
node.content:
Sealing RV seams is important because water damage often happens at the corners where RV walls are joined together. Although RV walls leave the factory with sealant already applied to the seams, over time UV light and weather breaks the sealant down. This creates gaps in the corners which allow moisture to get inside.

IMPORTANT: Never use silicone on the exterior of your RV for these reasons:

  • It does not stick to itself, so when it needs to be repaired, you need to remove all the silicone.
  • It's extremely difficult to remove!
  • It doesn't have good adhesion on smooth surfaces and is prone to peeling.
  • Over time it drys to a hard finish and cracks.
node.imagealttext: Travel Trailer Resealing|Prepping for camper reseal|Tape for RV Seals|Heat Gun for new RV seals|How to Reseal an RV|Reseal an RV
node.accordion_0_accordion_body:
• Pro Flex® RV sealant or Dicor Non-Sag Lap Sealant
  • Frogtape Painters Tape
  • Acetone
  • Gloves
node.accordion_1_accordion_body:
• Heat Gun
  • Plastic Tools
node.instructions_0_instructions_content: Look for any seams that are cracked or have gaps.
node.instructions_1_instructions_content: Using a heat gun, heat the old sealant till it's soft and scrape it out with a plastic pick or regular screwdriver. If you use a screwdriver, be careful not to scratch your paint. You want to remove the majority of the old sealant before adding new.
node.instructions_2_instructions_content: Clean the area with acetone to make sure all residue and debris are removed.
node.instructions_3_instructions_content: Tape off both sides of the seam that you'll be resealing. This allows for a clean edge.
node._yoast_wpseo_metadesc: Learn how to reseal the seams of your RV or camper by following easy step-by-step instructions, find links to all recommended paint products, and more.
node.instructions_4_instructions_content: Apply a bead of sealant with a caulk gun. If you're using Pro Flex® RV or Dicor Non-Sag Lap Sealant, be sure to smooth the bead with your finger in small sections. The caulk skins over pretty quickly. NOTE: The sealant is very sticky, so you'll want rags handy or wear gloves.
node.instructions_5_instructions_content: Let the sealant dry for 24 hrs and then remove the painter's tape. <ins class="adsbygoogle" style="display: block; text-align: center;" data-ad-layout="in-article" data-ad-format="fluid" data-ad-client="ca-pub-3133257559155527" data-ad-slot="1168701770"></ins>
